column6: Tax governance, control, and risk management
column13: QBE seeks to comply with all applicable tax laws, regulations, and disclosure requirements and pay the tax required in all jurisdictions we operate. Where compliance processes have been outsourced, we ensure that the service provider adheres to this principle.
column24: Location from Tax Transparency Report Page 5

column6: Tax governance, control, and risk management
column13: QBE maintains a robust tax risk management framework in its internal control processes. The framework identifies, assesses, and manages tax risks and accounts for them appropriately.
column24: Location from Tax Transparency Report Page 5

column6: Tax governance, control, and risk management
column13: The Board of QBE oversees global tax governance through QBE's tax risk management framework, with local boards overseeing divisional tax governance. Operationally, the Group CFO owns tax risk management and is responsible for ensuring the implementation of QBE's tax risk management framework with assistance from the Group Head of Tax and divisional CFOs.
column24: Location from Tax Transparency Report Page 5

column6: Tax governance, control, and risk management
column13: QBE engages in efficient tax planning that supports our business and reflects commercial and economic activity. No transaction will be entered where obtaining a tax benefit is the primary purpose. QBE does not engage in artificial tax arrangements, and we conduct transactions between Group companies on an arm's length basis based on current Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) principles.
column24: Location from Tax Transparency Report Page 6

column6: Stakeholder engagement and management of concerns related to tax
column13: QBE seeks to collaborate with tax authorities wherever possible to achieve early agreement and certainty and resolve any possible disputes. It also appropriately develops tax laws directly or through trade associations and other similar bodies.\t
column24: Location from Tax Transparency Report Page 6

column6: Stakeholder engagement and management of concerns related to tax

column13: QBE seeks to obtain benefits through collaboration across its international operations, pooling risks and resources, and leveraging international centres of excellence. It also seeks to ensure that transactions between related parties are undertaken on an arm's length basis by OECD principles and compliance with the legislative and administrative guidelines of the relevant taxation authorities.

column13: Contracts with electricity suppliers are agreements between consumers or businesses and electricity suppliers to purchase electricity for their energy needs. Contracts with electricity suppliers are critical in ensuring a reliable, affordable, and sustainable energy supply for consumers and businesses while establishing clear rights, obligations, and protections for both parties involved in the agreement.
column24: Location from Sustainability Data Book in DB Focus Area 1

column13: A purchase of an unbundled energy attribute certificate (EAC) refers to the procurement of certificates representing the environmental attributes of renewable energy generation that are separate from the physical electricity itself. These certificates, also known as Renewable Energy Certificates (RECs) in some regions, are issued for each unit of renewable electricity generated and are used to track and verify the renewable energy attributes associated with electricity production.
column24: Location from Sustainability Data Book in DB Focus Area 1

column8: Automated lighting controls with motion sensors and automatic
column13: By installing automated lighting controls with motion sensors and automatic functionality, QBE can improve energy efficiency, enhance comfort and convenience, and create a more sustainable and user-friendly environment for occupants. These systems help reduce energy waste by ensuring that lights are only activated when needed and can contribute to lower utility costs and environmental impact over time.

column13: Maintaining a low carbon risk refers to the actions taken by QBE to minimize or mitigate the potential financial, operational, and reputational risks associated with climate change and carbon emissions. These measures include implementing measures to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and transition to low-carbon or carbon-neutral operations.

Maintaining carbon neutrality on a defined inventory demonstrates a commitment to mitigating climate change, reducing environmental impacts, and contributing to global efforts to achieve net-zero emissions. It helps QBE align with sustainability goals, meet stakeholder expectations, and enhance its reputation as a responsible corporate citizen.

Transitioning your fleet to low-emissions vehicles means replacing or upgrading QBE's fleet with vehicles that produce fewer greenhouse gas emissions than traditional gasoline or diesel-powered vehicles. It can help reduce greenhouse gas emissions, improve air quality, and lower operating costs.

Installed solar panels enable property owners to generate clean, renewable energy from sunlight, reduce electricity costs, and lower their carbon footprint. They provide a sustainable and environmentally friendly alternative to conventional energy sources, contribute to efforts to combat climate change and promote renewable energy adoption.

Renewable electricity sources offer numerous benefits, including reducing greenhouse gas emissions, mitigating climate change, enhancing energy security, diversifying energy supplies, and creating economic opportunities. They are a vital component of the transition to a sustainable, low-carbon energy system and play a crucial role in meeting global energy demand and minimizing environmental impact.
column24: Location from Sustainability Data Book in DB Focus Area 1

column13: Setting an internal carbon price involves establishing a monetary value or cost per metric ton of carbon dioxide equivalent (CO2e) emissions within the organization. This hypothetical price is a financial tool to account for the costs associated with greenhouse gas emissions and incentivize emissions reductions throughout the organization.
